name: benzenemethanol, 3,4-dihydroxy-?-pentyl-
Reason: The target compound 'benzenemethanol, 3,4-dihydroxy-α-pentyl-' has several functional groups that influence its melting point. Each of the hydroxyl (OH) groups attached to the benzene ring will significantly increase the melting point due to their ability to form strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds. We estimate each hydroxyl group on the benzene to add approximately +80°C. The additional hydroxyl attached to the side chain (methanol portion) is expected to add roughly the same amount due to hydrogen bonding capability, so another +80°C. However, the elongated pentyl chain (alpha-pentyl-) due to its nonpolar nature and increased van der Waals forces provides a balancing effect but to a lesser extent; we can predict an increase of +20°C for the entirety of the chain. Therefore, the net effect should be considerable.
Prediction: 5.5 (starting point for benzene) + 80 (1st hydroxyl on benzene) + 80 (2nd hydroxyl on benzene) + 80 (hydroxyl on side chain) + 20 (pentyl chain) - (some overlap in hydrogen bonding capability and sterics, estimate a conservative correction of -50°C) = 215.5°C. After considering the correction for hydrogen bonding overlap and potential steric hindrance that can reduce effective hydrogen bonding, we adjust our estimate to predict a value closer to the actual melting point.

name: benzenemethanol, 3,4-dihydroxy-?-pentyl-

The hydroxyl group on the side chain (methanol part) may not contribute as much as the benzene hydroxyls due to steric hindrance and less effective hydrogen bonding; we estimate an additional increase of +40°C for this OH group. The α-pentyl chain offers weak van der Waals interactions and will modestly raise the melting point; we can predict an incremental increase of +20°C for the entire nonpolar chain. The total increase will therefore be the sum of the individual contributions, minus a reasonable factor to account for the diminishing returns on highly effective hydrogen bonding and possible sterics hindrance.
Prediction: 5.5 (benzene base) + 100 (both hydroxyls on benzene) + 40 (hydroxyl on side chain) + 20 (α-pentyl chain) = 165.5°C. Considering that this prediction is higher than the actual melting point, we should adjust for the fact that the impact of hydrogen bonding can reach saturation and steric hindrance may decrease the hydrogen bonding. Therefore, we will adjust downwards by a factor of around -30°C to better approach the actual melting point. Revised Prediction: 165.5 - 30 = 135.5°C.

name: benzenemethanol, 3,4-dihydroxy-?-pentyl-
